addressleaf.section:
To
e right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasuror of England

21 Julij
1594
M
r
Bodley to my L.
From
e Haghe.
M
o
s
de Car
o
ad
v
tism
e
t of
e request made to h
y
e 15 of Julij
t
he was c
o
term
a
ded by
S
Ro. Cecills
l
re

page.lettertext:
fol.55r
May it please yo
r
good L. assoone as I had
sealed my former unto yo
w
, upon a newe adver-
tisment sent hither from M
r
Caron to
e
states,
there
were certaine deputed to conferre againe w
t
me, and
to learne w
at
I could signifie, as touching those de-
maundes w
ch
were made by her
Ma
tie
and proposed
to M
r
Caron
e
15
of this moneth, in yo
r
L. house in
Lond
o
. But declaring unto them at I had not
understoode
e particular pointes, they imparted
them unto me, and signified w
t
all, That for 9 or
10 shippes
for 3 monethes required of her Ma
tie
they
did not thinke
at
e contrey would make any diffi-
cultie: nor for
e
twentie thousand weight of powder.
But they could not comprehend w
at
was meant by
at
point, wherein her Ma
tie
doth desire, to be
served of 2
monethes victuals, for two thousand men. For they doe
presume
at all kinde of victuals are more abundant,
and better cheape, and more ready for
at service in
England
then heere: and
at they can not well carie
for more then 3 monethes victuals. Againe they
seemed to mervaile,
at if it were intended,
at
e
Fort before Brest should be taken from
e Enemie,
there was no mention made of
munition, and
at of
powder in like maner so smalle a quantitie was de-
maunded.
for
at in these contreis they doe make
provision at
e lest, at
e siege of any place,
at is
of importance, of two hundred thowsand weight,
and of fivetie thowsand onely to serve for
e smalle
shotte. I could not tell what to answear to
any of these doubtes, because I had receaved no co-
mission about it, nor was not rashely to conjecture
at her Ma
ties
meaning. Howbeit perceaving by
their speeches,
at they would not shrinke in their as-
sistance, but were rather inclined to affourd a greater
proportion of every thing demuanded then was mentioned
by her Ma
tie
I solicited them in
at behalf, declaring
fol.55v
for
e rest,
at
I thought
those demaundes were onely made by
way of communication, and proceeded of an unper-
fect project cast upon
e first meeting onely, and
that they should be throughly satisfied, when I had
my letters, w
ch
I expected every houre. Wherupon they
concluded,
at for
e reasons alleaged, at
e time of
my Audience (w
ch
I have sette downe in my former
to yo
r
L.) and because M
r
Caron
e very same day
at he had speeche w
t
her Ma
tie
in yo
r
L. house, recea-
ved after a letter from S
r
Robert Cecill, wherein he
was req
e
sted in her Ma
ties
name, to stay his dispatche
for
at she had not yet taken a full resolution, they
could not take order upon any thing proposed, but
presently upon notice of her determinat final purpose,
and some 16 or 20 daies warning
, they would be
ready w
t
their navie, and all thinges appertening.
And thus I take my humble leave. From
e Hag
e
July 21 1594.
Yo
r
L most humble at commaundem
t
Tho. Bodley
